title: Data Input for pandemonium
text: launch app, user needs provide data frame observations. automatically sort variables numeric variables, well impute missing data using VIM::kNN() VIM installed otherwise entries misssing data removed. Numeric variables can sorted clustering space (space1) linked space (space2) loaded app data screen. Variables can added removed space drop selector appears clicking box.  Alternatively, data can passed two separate arrays clustering variables df = space1 linked variables space2 = space2. select space 1 2 data screen loading app. can done like :
code: pandemonium(df = Bikes$df) pandemonium(df = Bikes$space1, space2 = Bikes$space2)

title: Data Input for pandemonium
text: complete input pandemonium() includes optional data function inputs. inputs shown following call.

title: Understanding the dimReduction Function Input
text: vignette describes usage dimReduction parameter pandemonium app new functions can written . input dimReduction named list functions, function defines dimension reduction needs structured follows.

title: Understanding the dimReduction Function Input
text: mat = n x m matrix coordinates reduce dist = n x n distance matrix typically one two used dimension reduction, interface requires arguments accepted avoid errors.

title: Understanding the dimReduction Function Input
text: list object contains output dimension reduction can accessed dimReduction(mat = mat, dist = dist)$Y = n x 2 matrix data frame dimension reduced coordinates observations.

title: Understanding the dimReduction Function Input
text: standard way write new function passed dimReduction wrapper common dimension reduction algorithm. defined function must able take mat dist parameters. one used best write function space additional parameters ... seen following example. algorithms may take dist object instead distance matrix. can done converting distance matrix using stats::.dist(). example implementation umap.
code: tSNE_mat <- function(mat, ...) {   coord_red <- list()   coord_red$Y <- Rtsne::Rtsne(mat)$Y   coord_red }  tSNE_dist <- function(dist, ...) {   coord_red <- list()   coord_red$Y <- Rtsne::Rtsne(dist, is.dist = TRUE)$Y   coord_red }  newPandemonium(df, dim_reduction = list(tSNE_mat = tSNE_mat, tSNE_dist = tSNE_dist)) umap <- function(dist, ...) {   ret <- list()   ret$Y <- uwot::umap(stats::as.dist(dist))   ret }  newPandemonium(df, dim_reduction = list(umap = umap))

title: Understanding the getCoords Function Input
text: Used externally calculated coordinates, cut computation time coordinate function otherwise written. closure coordinate function returns user defined coordinate matrix passed closure called pandemonium call pandemonium(df, getCoords=list(user=userCoords(coordMatrix))). used variables removed space GUI. Externally calculated coordinates can used userCoords input data rawCoords used coordinate function. use userCoords rawCoords treatment input data. pandemonium displays input data many plots use coordinates input data result plots less meaningful interpretation. Use userCoords coordinates necessary calculate distances interpretation plots clustering space necessary.

title: Understanding the getCoords Function Input
text: function return single array size input df column names df.

title: Understanding the getCoords Function Input
code: pullCoordsNoCov <- function(df, cov, exp, ...) {   n <- nrow(df)   df <- as.matrix(df)   nc <- ncol(df)   coord_mat <- matrix(nrow = n, ncol = nc)    for (i in 1:n) {     for (j in 1:nc) {       coord_mat[i, j] <- as.numeric((df[i, j] - exp$value[j]) / sqrt(cov[j, j]))     }   }   colnames(coord_mat) <- colnames(df)   return(coord_mat) }  pandemonium(df, getCoords = list(pull = pullCoordsNoCov, normal = normCoords))

title: Understanding the getScore Function Input
text: vignette describes usage getScore parameter pandemonium app. input function calculates scores bins plotted input panel can used colouring dimension reduction tour views. pandemonium package provides two functions scores one can created passed. two functions provided : chi2score calculate chi-squared values exp reference point space1. scores returned chi-squared values, bins sigma bins reference point interesting points ‘bf’, best fit ‘sm’, closet point origin. outsidescore function takes set scores point name score data outside app. passed loading app. scores returned scores passed , bins quartile bins score interesting points returned.

title: Understanding the getScore Function Input
text: app pass following objects getScore may used calculations:

title: Understanding the getScore Function Input
text: function return named list following entries used app.

title: Understanding the getScore Function Input
text: simple template getScore function look like follows: function take values outside app, best write closure pass values calling app. done outsidescore seen :
code: myScore <- function(space1 = rv$space1, cov = rv$cov1, covinv = rv$covInv1,                     exp = rv$exp, space2 = rv$space2, space2.cov = rv$cov2,                     space2.exp = rv$space2.exp, k = rv$kC) {   ## Calculations   n <- nrow(space1)   scores <- # function to calculate scores     bins <- # function to bin scores      ## Return     ret <- list()   ret$score <- scores   ret$scoreName <- "scores"   ret$bins <- bins   ret$binName <- "bins"   ret$interest <- rep("", n)   ret$is.interest <- which(ret$interest != "")   ret }  pandemonium(df, getScore = myScore) outsideScore <- function(scores, scoreName = NULL) {   function(space1, ...) {     ret <- list()     n <- nrow(space1)     ret$score <- scores     ret$bins <- cut(scores, stats::quantile(scores, c(0, 0.25, 0.75, 1)) - c(1, 0, 0, 0), labels = c("lower", "inner", "upper"))     ret$interest <- rep("", n)     ret$is.interest <- which(ret$interest != "")     ret$scoreName <- as.character(scoreName)     ret$binName <- "quartile"     ret   } }  pandemonium(   df = Bikes$space1, space2 = Bikes$space2,   getScore = outsideScore(Bikes$other$res, "Residual") )

title: How to Use makePlots
text: vignette describes usage makePlots() function. makePlots function generate plots seen GUI outside , can saved shared. Plots random non deterministic outcomes seed set can reproduced. makePlots got inputs pandemonium (see “Data input pandemonium”) exception settings. replaces GUI app one named list define settings. Two small differences input function follows. CovInv specified space. Coordinate functions passed named list instead functions passed getCoordsSpace1 getCoordsSpace2.

title: How to Use makePlots
text: named list settings values must specified every call makePlots others optional required certain plots. required values every call follows: linkage can one following: “complete”, “single”, “average”, “median”, “centroid”, “mcquitty”, “ward.D”, “ward.D2” metric can one following: “euclidean”, “maximum”, “manhattan”, “canberra”,“binary”, “minkowski”,“user”

what: High Dimensional Analysis in Linked Spaces
title: High Dimensional Analysis in Linked Spaces
text: pandemonium performs hierarchical cluster analysis within Shiny GUI. data space split two parts, example input variables latent variables statistical model. Clustering performed using subset variables clustering space, cluster assignments also visualised linked space. Within dynamic GUI pandemonium performs data preparation, clustering visualisation interactive methods. user can change settings without leave GUI.

title: High Dimensional Analysis in Linked Spaces
text: latest release version pandemonium can installed CRAN : can install development version pandemonium GitHub :

title: High Dimensional Analysis in Linked Spaces
text: use Bikes data example show app can used. load GUI data, following can used. loading app clustering space df linked space space2 data automatically selected data page. pressing load app launch analysis tab. Within analysis tab can explore different visualisations options enclosed tabs.
code: library(pandemonium) pandemonium(df = Bikes$space1, space2 = Bikes$space2,                  getScore = outsideScore(Bikes$other$res,"Residual"))

what: Bike sharing data with model information — Bikes
title: Bike sharing data with model information — Bikes
text: dataset contains daily counts bikes rented corresponding weather seasonal information. data provided Hadi Fanaee-T available https://doi.org/10.24432/C5W894. Additionally, model information single hidden layer neural network eight nodes hidden layer added: values activations observations (variables A1 A8 cluster space) model prediction (pred) residual (res) variables.

title: Bike sharing data with model information — Bikes
Bike sharing data with model information — Bikes
text: list 4 dataframes df dataframe 731 obs 18 variables containing entire bikes data set space1 dataframe 731 obs 8 variables (cluster space) space2 dataframe 731 obs 6 variables (linked space, predictors used model) dataframe 731 obs 4 variables (variables, including observed predicted counts)

title: Compute cluster information — getBenchmarkInformation
code: dists <- getDists(Bikes$space1, "euclidean") fit <- stats::hclust(dists, "ward.D2") groups <- stats::cutree(fit, k = 4) getBenchmarkInformation(as.matrix(dists), groups) #> # A tibble: 4 × 4 #>      id     r     d group #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1   300 0.914  4.36     1 #> 2   363 1.75   2.99     2 #> 3   244 1.21   2.61     3 #> 4   485 1.56   3.96     4

code: dists <- getDists(Bikes$space1, "euclidean") fit <- stats::hclust(dists, "ward.D2") groups <- stats::cutree(fit, k = 4) bm <- getBenchmarkInformation(as.matrix(dists), groups) getClusterDists(as.matrix(dists), groups, bm) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>     grA   grB    d1     d2    d3 #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     1     2  2.69 0.397   5.76 #> 2     1     3  1.96 0.571   5.16 #> 3     1     4  2.72 0.422   6.00 #> 4     2     3  1.99 0.0643  3.82 #> 5     2     4  2.23 0.212   4.71 #> 6     3     4  1.56 0.793   3.81

title: Generate a specified plot outside the GUI — makePlots
code: makePlots(   space1 = Bikes$space1,   settings = list(     plotType = "WC", x = "hum", y = "temp", k = 4, metric = "euclidean",     linkage = "ward.D2", WCa = 0.5, showalpha = TRUE   ), cov = cov(Bikes$space1),   space2 = Bikes$space2, getScore = outsidescore(Bikes$other$res, "Residual") ) #> Error in outsidescore(Bikes$other$res, "Residual"): could not find function "outsidescore"  makePlots(   space1 = Bikes$space1,   settings = list(     plotType = "tour", k = 4, metric = "euclidean", linkage = "ward.D2",     tourspace = "space1", colouring = "clustering", out_dim = 2, tour_path = "grand",     display = "scatter", radial_start = NULL, radial_var = NULL, slice_width = NULL, seed = 2025   ),   cov = cov(Bikes$space1), space2 = Bikes$space2,   getScore = outsidescore(Bikes$other$res, "Residual") ) #> Error in outsidescore(Bikes$other$res, "Residual"): could not find function "outsidescore"

text: Computes non-linear dimension reduction Rtsne default parameters.

title: function to make tours — tourMaker
text: coord1 coordinate matrix space 1 coord2 coordinate matrix space 2 group grouping assignment score score assignments user_group user defined grouping tourspace space show tour colouring colouring use plot out_dim dimension output tour tour_path tour path type use, one ("grand","cmass","holes","lda","pda","dcor","spline","radial","anomaly") display display type, one ("scatter","slice") radial_start projection use start radial tour, one ("random","cmass","holes","lda","pda","dcor","spline") radial_var variable remove radial tour slice_width width slice seed sets seed

title: User defined coordinate function — userCoords
text: Externally calculated coordinates can used userCoords input data rawCoords used coordinate function. use userCoords rawCoords treatment input data. pandemonium displays input data many plots use coordinates input data result plots less meaningful interpretation. Use userCoords coordinates necessary calculate distances interpretation plots clustering space necessary.

title: User defined coordinate function — userCoords
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() pandemonium(   df = Bikes$space1, space2 = Bikes$space2,   coords = list(normalised = normCoords, space2 = userCoords(Bikes$space2)) ) }

what: Write coordinates and cluster assignment to a CSV file — writeResults
title: Write coordinates and cluster assignment to a CSV file — writeResults
text: working results outside app. Settings used: metric, linkage, k

title: Write coordinates and cluster assignment to a CSV file — writeResults
code: writeResults(   space1,   cov = NULL,   covInv = NULL,   exp = NULL,   space2,   space2.cov = NULL,   space2.covInv = NULL,   space2.exp = NULL,   settings,   filename,   user_dist = NULL,   getCoords.space1 = normCoords,   getCoords.space2 = rawCoords )

title: Write coordinates and cluster assignment to a CSV file — writeResults
text: space1 cluster space matrix cov covariance matrix covInv inverse covariance matrix exp observable reference value (e.g. experimental measurement) space2 space2 matrix space2.cov covariance matrix space2.covInv inverse covariance matrix space2.exp observable reference value (e.g. experimental measurement) settings list specifying parameters usually selected app filename path write results file user_dist input distance matrix (optional) getCoords.space1 function calculate coordinates clustering space getCoords.space2 function calculate coordinates linked space

title: Write coordinates and cluster assignment to a CSV file — writeResults
text: return value, called writing file

title: Write coordinates and cluster assignment to a CSV file — writeResults
code: file <- tempfile() writeResults(   space1 = Bikes$space1, space2 = Bikes$space2,   settings = list(metric = "euclidean", linkage = "ward.D2", k = 4), filename = file ) file.remove(file) #> [1] TRUE
